facts.text: Three appeals arise out of three separate trials before the Additional Sessions Judge, Bulandshahr.

anchor.surface_text: Mudholkar, J. These three appeals arise out of three separate trials before the Additional Sessions Judge, Bulandshahr, but were argued together as they raise identical questions.

facts.text: Appellant was a postman attached to the Bulandshahr post office.

anchor.surface_text: In all these trials, the appellant, who was a postman attached to the Bulandshahr post office was tried for offences under s. 52 of the Indian Post Office Act, 1898  VI of 1898 ,

facts.text: Appellant tried for offences under s. 52 of the Indian Post Office Act, 1898, and in two cases also under ss. 467 and 471 of the Indian Penal Code.

anchor.surface_text: and in two of them, also for offences under ss. 467 and 471 of the Indian Penal Code. Briefly stated the allegations against the appellant were that he either stole or secreted five registered letters and that he fabricated three receipts showing that the registered letters were received by the addressees.

facts.text: Allegations against appellant: stole or secreted five registered letters and fabricated three receipts showing receipt by addressees.

anchor.surface_text: Briefly stated the allegations against the appellant were that he either stole or secreted five registered letters and that he fabricated three receipts showing that the registered letters were received by the addressees.

facts.text: Additional Sessions Judge acquitted appellant of all offences.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Additional Sessions Judge acquitted the appellant of all these offences.

facts.text: State appealed against acquittal to High Court of Allahabad, restricted to offences under s. 52 of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: The State then preferred an appeal against his acquittal in these three cases to the High Court of Allahabad but restricted the appeal to the acquittal of the appellant in respect of offences under s. 52 of the Indian Post Office Act, 1898  hereafter referred to as the Act .

facts.text: High Court held appellant secreted the five registered letters, set aside acquittal, convicted under s. 52, sentenced to RI one year in each case.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court held that the appellant had secreted the five registered letters in question and on this finding set aside his acquittal and convicted him in each of the three appeals for offences under s. 52 of the Act and sentenced him to undergo rigorous imprisonment for a period of one year in each case.

facts.text: Appellant came to Supreme Court by special leave.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant has come up to this Court by special leave.

facts.text: House search on May 12, 1956 by CID Inspector S. N. Singh and SI Masood Murtaza in connection with case against Greenwood Publicity.

anchor.surface_text: Briefly stated the prosecution case is that when the house in which the appellant lives along with his father Diwan Singh, a retired Police Head Constable, was searched by the C.I.D. Inspector, S. N. Singh, along with Masood Murtaza, Sub-Inspector of Police, Bulandshahr on May 12, 1956 in connection with a case against Greenwood Publicity,

facts.text: During search, accidentally discovered large number of letters, postcards, and five registered letters.

anchor.surface_text: they accidentally discovered a large number of letters and postcards and also the five registered letters in question.

facts.text: Appellant lives with father Diwan Singh, retired Police Head Constable.

anchor.surface_text: when the house in which the appellant lives along with his father Diwan Singh, a retired Police Head Constable,

facts.text: At time of search, appellant was away on leave at Delhi for postal conference.

anchor.surface_text: At the time of the search the appellant who happens to be a trade union official, was not in Bulandshahr but was away on leave at Delhi in connection with a postal conference.

facts.text: Articles found in almirah, key produced by appellant's father.

anchor.surface_text: There articles were found in an almirah, the key of which was produced by the appellants father.

facts.text: Articles taken to Kotwali in sealed packet and listed there.

anchor.surface_text: The articles were not listed at the spot but were taken to the Kotwali in a sealed packet and later on listed there.

facts.text: Appellant's defence: articles planted by opposite party at Kotwali due to factions in post office.

anchor.surface_text: Briefly, the appellants defence in all these cases is that there are two factions in the Bulandshahr post office and that these articles were planted by the opposite party. According to him, the planting must have occurred in the Kotwali when the Sub-Inspector purported to make a list of the articles seized from the house in which the appellant lives.

facts.text: House consists of two rooms, rented in father's name, both live there, almirah in father's possession, key produced by him. This fact is not denied.

anchor.surface_text: Further, according to him, neither the house nor the almirah from which the articles are said to have been seized was in his exclusive possession. He stated - and that fact is not denied - that the house which consists of two rooms only has been rented in his fathers name, that both of them live in those two rooms and that the almirah was in his fathers possession inasmuch as the key was produced by him.

facts.text: Recovery of letters 7 or 8 months after dispatch.

anchor.surface_text: because that recovery was made 7 or 8 months after those letters had been dispatched

facts.text: Acknowledgements purporting to be from addressees for at least three registered letters were with post office.

anchor.surface_text: He further referred to the fact that at least in respect of three of the registered letters acknowledgements purporting to be from the addressee were obtained and were with the post office.

facts.text: Addressees examined and deposed they did not receive the letters; evidence believed by High Court.

anchor.surface_text: The addressees have been examined in this case and they have deposed that the letters in question were not received by them. Their evidence has been believed by the High Court

facts.text: High Court reasons for possession: appellant alone had opportunity, nine articles addressed to him, father old man wouldn't incriminate son, appellant had motive.

anchor.surface_text: Dealing with this question the High Court has observed as follows In the first place, the respondent alone had the opportunity and the means to secure such a large number of postal articles.  2  that at least nine of those postal articles were addressed to the respondent himself  vide Ex. Ka-9, serial number 66 ,  3  that Dewan Singh, who, we are informed is a very old man, would not foist the said incriminating articles on his son and thus ruin his career for ever, and  4  that the respondent alone can be said to have had some motive for secreting and concealing the registered letters and other postal articles in question.

facts.text: Supreme Court held prosecution failed to prove letters in exclusive possession of appellant.

anchor.surface_text: In the circumstances we must hold that the prosecution has failed to prove that these letters were in the exclusive possession of the appellant.

facts.text: Almirah contained articles belonging to father and appellant.

anchor.surface_text: The circumstance that the almirah contained, apart from the registered letters in question, certain other articles belonging to the appellant cannot sustain an inference that the almirah was in the appellants possession exclusively or even jointly with his father.

facts.text: Key of almirah produced by father, no evidence it was with appellant.

anchor.surface_text: As the key was produced by the appellants father and there is no evidence that it was ever with the appellant

facts.text: Sentences in three cases ordered to run consecutively.

anchor.surface_text: The sentences in the three cases having been ordered to run consecutively the total sentence is excessive.

facts.text: Search in contravention of ss. 103 and 165 CrPC alleged.

anchor.surface_text: That the search was illegal inasmuch as it was in contravention of the provisions of ss. 103 and 165 of the Code of Criminal Procedure.

anchor.surface_text: So far as the alleged illegality of the search is concerned it is sufficient to say that even assuming that the search was illegal the seizure of the articles is not vitiated. It may be that where the provisions of ss. 103 and 165, Code of Criminal Procedure, are contravened the search could be resisted by the person whose premises are sought to be searched. It may also be that because of the illegality of the search the Court may be inclined to examine carefully the evidence regarding the seizure. But beyond these two consequences no further consequence ensues.

concepts.interpretation: Illegal search allows resistance and careful scrutiny but does not vitiate seizure or trial; court accepts prosecution evidence on seizure.

arguments.claim: No entrustment required for secretion, destruction etc. under s.52 Post Office Act

anchor.surface_text: The first act referred to in this section is theft. Surely it cannot be contended that any entrustment is necessary with regard to that act. ... Further, a perusal of s. 55 makes it clear that where the entrustment of an article is made an ingredient of an offence,

arguments.claim: Retention of postal article in almirah by post office officer for inordinately long period amounts to secreting

anchor.surface_text: To secrete means, according to the dictionary to hide. In connection with a postal article addressed to some person the fact that it is retained in his possession by an officer of the post office in an almirah and that too for an inordinately long period would be tantamount to hiding that article.

arguments.claim: Postal articles in almirah 7-8 months later still in course of transmission per s.3(a)

anchor.surface_text: The expression in course of transmission by post has been defined in s. 3 a of the Act as follows a postal article shall be deemed to be in course of transmission by post from the time of its being delivered to a Post Office to the time of its being delivered to the addressee or of its being returned to the sender or otherwise disposed of under Chap. VII.

arguments.claim: Prosecution failed to prove letters in exclusive possession of appellant; joint at best

anchor.surface_text: In the circumstances we must hold that the prosecution has failed to prove that these letters were in the exclusive possession of the appellant. No presumption can, therefore, be drawn against him that he had secreted them from the mere fact that they were found in the almirah which, at best, may be regarded as being in the joint possession of himself and his father.

holdings.text: Even assuming that the search was illegal the seizure of the articles is not vitiated. It may be that where the provisions of ss. 103 and 165, Code of Criminal Procedure, are contravened the search could be resisted by the person whose premises are sought to be searched. It may also be that because of the illegality of the search the Court may be inclined to examine carefully the evidence regarding the seizure. But beyond these two consequences no further consequence ensues.

anchor.surface_text: So far as the alleged illegality of the search is concerned it is sufficient to say that even assuming that the search was illegal the seizure of the articles is not vitiated. It may be that where the provisions of ss. 103 and 165, Code of Criminal Procedure, are contravened the search could be resisted by the person whose premises are sought to be searched.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Illegal search permits resistance and careful scrutiny of seizure evidence but does not invalidate the seizure or trial.

holdings.text: The High Court has chosen to accept the evidence of the prosecution with regard to the fact of seizure and that being a question to be decided only by the Court of fact, this Court would not re-examine the evidence for satisfying itself as to the correctness or otherwise of the conclusions reached by the High Court.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court has chosen to accept the evidence of the prosecution with regard to the fact of seizure and that being a question to be decided only by the Court of fact, this Court would not re-examine the evidence for satisfying itself as to the correctness or otherwise of the conclusions reached by the High Court.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Factual findings on seizure accepted by High Court not re-examined by Supreme Court.

holdings.text: No grievance was made either before the Court of the Additional Sessions Judge or before the High Court that there was such a contravention and the appellant was prejudiced and we cannot allow the point to be raised for the first time here, the reason being that whether there was prejudice is a question of fact and cannot be permitted to be agitated for the first time in an appeal under Art. 136 of the Constitution.

anchor.surface_text: In so far as the contravention of provisions of s. 342, Code of Criminal Procedure, are concerned it is sufficient to point out that no grievance was made either before the Court of the Additional Sessions Judge or before the High Court that there was such a contravention and the appellant was prejudiced and we cannot allow the point to be raised for the first time here, the reason being that whether there was prejudice is a question of fact and cannot be permitted to be agitated for the first time in an appeal under Art. 136 of the Constitution.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Procedural irregularity under s.342 not raised below; prejudice is factual issue not entertainable first time under Art.136.

holdings.text: This Court has held that an appeal from acquittal need not be treated differently from an appeal from conviction and if the High Court finds that the acquittal is not justified by the evidence on record it can set aside the acquittal without coming to the conclusion that there were compelling reasons for doing so.

anchor.surface_text: As regards the fifth point, it is sufficient to say that this Court has held that an appeal from acquittal need not be treated differently from an appeal from conviction and if the High Court finds that the acquittal is not justified by the evidence on record it can set aside the acquittal without coming to the conclusion that there were compelling reasons for doing so.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Appeals against acquittal treated like conviction appeals; no compelling reasons required if evidence does not justify acquittal.

holdings.text: Bearing in mind the fact that the maximum sentence awarded under s. 52 of the Act is seven years it would not be right to say that in ordering the sentences in the three cases to run consecutively the appellant is being very severely punished.

anchor.surface_text: In so far as the sentence is concerned, bearing in mind the fact that the maximum sentence awarded under s. 52 of the Act is seven years it would not be right to say that in ordering the sentences in the three cases to run consecutively the appellant is being very severely punished.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Three years RI consecutive not excessive given seven-year maximum under s.52.

holdings.text: No entrustment is necessary for the acts specified in s.52 such as theft, dishonest misappropriation, secretion, destruction or throwing away of postal articles by post office officer.

anchor.surface_text: The first act referred to in this section is theft. Surely it cannot be contended that any entrustment is necessary with regard to that act. ... Further, a perusal of s. 55 makes it clear that where the entrustment of an article is made an ingredient of an offence, the legislature has used appropriate words to make the matter clear.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual contrast with s.55 which requires entrustment; purposive to cover access without entrustment to prevent tampering.

holdings.text: To secrete means, according to the dictionary to hide. In connection with a postal article addressed to some person the fact that it is retained in his possession by an officer of the post office in an almirah and that too for an inordinately long period would be tantamount to hiding that article.

anchor.surface_text: But, according to Mr. Misra, the appellant cannot be said to have secreted the letter just because it was found in the almirah which is said to have been in his exclusive possession. To secrete means, according to the dictionary to hide. In connection with a postal article addressed to some person the fact that it is retained in his possession by an officer of the post office in an almirah and that too for an inordinately long period would be tantamount to hiding that article.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Dictionary meaning applied to facts; long retention by post officer = hiding.

holdings.text: A postal article shall be deemed to be in course of transmission by post from the time of its being delivered to a Post Office to the time of its being delivered to the addressee or of its being returned to the sender or otherwise disposed of under Chap. VII.

anchor.surface_text: The expression in course of transmission by post has been defined in s. 3 a  of the Act as follows a postal article shall be deemed to be in course of transmission by post from the time of its being delivered to a Post Office to the time of its being delivered to the addressee or of its being returned to the sender or otherwise disposed of under Chap. VII.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Statutory definition per s.3(a); delay does not end transmission until delivery/return/disposal.

holdings.text: The existence of these acknowledgements would no more than raise a presumption that those articles were delivered to the addressees. The addressees have been examined in this case and they have deposed that the letters in question were not received by them. Their evidence has been believed by the High Court and therefore, there is an end to the matter.

anchor.surface_text: As regards the other point, that is, based on the fact that there were acknowledgements in respect of three letters in the post office we may point out that the existence of these acknowledgements would no more than raise a presumption that those articles were delivered to the addressees. The addressees have been examined in this case and they have deposed that the letters in question were not received by them.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Acknowledgements raise rebuttable presumption; addressee denial accepted by High Court.

holdings.text: The prosecution has failed to prove that these letters were in the exclusive possession of the appellant. No presumption can, therefore, be drawn against him that he had secreted them from the mere fact that they were found in the almirah which, at best, may be regarded as being in the joint possession of himself and his father.

anchor.surface_text: In the circumstances we must hold that the prosecution has failed to prove that these letters were in the exclusive possession of the appellant. No presumption can, therefore, be drawn against him that he had secreted them from the mere fact that they were found in the almirah which, at best, may be regarded as being in the joint possession of himself and his father.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Joint possession with father (key holder) insufficient for exclusive possession inference; High Court reasons circular/speculative.

holdings.text: On the findings arrived at by the High Court no offence under s. 52 of the Post Office Act has been made out.

anchor.surface_text: In the circumstances we must hold that the prosecution has failed to prove that these letters were in the exclusive possession of the appellant. No presumption can, therefore, be drawn against him that he had secreted them from the mere fact that they were found in the almirah which, at best, may be regarded as being in the joint possession of himself and his father. But, as already stated, even an inference of joint possession would not be legitimate.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No exclusive possession proved, hence no secreting under s.52 despite opportunity/motive arguments rejected as circular.

anchor.surface_text: So far as the alleged illegality of the search is concerned it is sufficient to say that even assuming that the search was illegal the seizure of the articles is not vitiated. It may be that where the provisions of ss. 103 and 165, Code of Criminal Procedure, are contravened the search could be resisted by the person whose premises are sought to be searched.

In the circumstances we must hold that the prosecution has failed to prove that these letters were in the exclusive possession of the appellant. No presumption can, therefore, be drawn against him that he had secreted them from the mere fact that they were found in the almirah which, at best, may be regarded as being in the joint possession of himself and his father.

In the circumstances we must hold that the prosecution has failed to prove that these letters were in the exclusive possession of the appellant. No presumption can, therefore, be drawn against him that he had secreted them from the mere fact that they were found in the almirah which, at best, may be regarded as being in the joint possession of himself and his father.

In the circumstances we must hold that the prosecution has failed to prove that these letters were in the exclusive possession of the appellant. No presumption can, therefore, be drawn against him that he had secreted them from the mere fact that they were found in the almirah which, at best, may be regarded as being in the joint possession of himself and his father. But, as already stated, even an inference of joint possession would not be legitimate.

In the circumstances we must hold that the prosecution has failed to prove that these letters were in the exclusive possession of the appellant. No presumption can, therefore, be drawn against him that he had secreted them from the mere fact that they were found in the almirah which, at best, may be regarded as being in the joint possession of himself and his father.

anchor.surface_text: In so far as the contravention of provisions of s. 342, Code of Criminal Procedure, are concerned it is sufficient to point out that no grievance was made either before the Court of the Additional Sessions Judge or before the High Court that there was such a contravention and the appellant was prejudiced and we cannot allow the point to be raised for the first time here, the reason being that whether there was prejudice is a question of fact and cannot be permitted to be agitated for the first time in an appeal under Art. 136 of the Constitution.
differently from an appeal from companyviction and if the High Court finds that the acquittal is number justified by the evidence on record it can se

edges.explanation: Holding states that this Court has held appeal from acquittal need not be treated differently from conviction if acquittal not justified, grounding the concept.

anchor.surface_text: As regards the fifth point, it is sufficient to say that this Court has held that an appeal from acquittal need not be treated differently from an appeal from conviction and if the High Court finds that the acquittal is not justified by the evidence on record it can set aside the acquittal without coming to the conclusion that there were compelling reasons for doing so.

In so far as the sentence is concerned, bearing in mind the fact that the maximum sentence awarded under s. 52 of the Act is seven years it would not be right to say that in ordering the sentences in the three cases to run consecutively the appellant is being very severely punished.

anchor.surface_text: The first act referred to in this section is theft. Surely it cannot be contended that any entrustment is necessary with regard to that act. ... Further, a perusal of s. 55 makes it clear that where the entrustment of an article is made an ingredient of an offence, the legislature has used appropriate words to make the matter clear.

In the circumstances we must hold that the prosecution has failed to prove that these letters were in the exclusive possession of the appellant. No presumption can, therefore, be drawn against him that he had secreted them from the mere fact that they were found in the almirah which, at best, may be regarded as being in the joint possession of himself and his father.

edges.explanation: Holding h7 that retention for long period amounts to secreting supports c1 that retention in almirah tantamount to hiding

anchor.surface_text: But, according to Mr. Misra, the appellant cannot be said to have secreted the letter just because it was found in the almirah which is said to have been in his exclusive possession. To secrete means, according to the dictionary to hide. In connection with a postal article addressed to some person the fact that it is retained in his possession by an officer of the post office in an almirah and that too for an inordinately long period would be tantamount to hiding that article.

In the circumstances we must hold that the prosecution has failed to prove that these letters were in the exclusive possession of the appellant. No presumption can, therefore, be drawn against him that he had secreted them from the mere fact that they were found in the almirah which, at best, may be regarded as being in the joint possession of himself and his father.

VII.

In the circumstances we must hold that the prosecution has failed to prove that these letters were in the exclusive possession of the appellant. No presumption can, therefore, be drawn against him that he had secreted them from the mere fact that they were found in the almirah which, at best, may be regarded as being in the joint possession of himself and his father.
